page.title: 01Introduction
page.content: This part of North Staffordshire lies 8 miles E of Stoke-on-Trent. Straddling the beautiful, wooded Churnet valley, it flanks the Staffordshire Moorlands, the southern extension of the Pennines. The soils are based on sandstone and some clays. The land is much better for pasture than crops. Farming has always been important in the area. A number of old barns, cottages and farmhouses built from sandstone still survive. Some 200 years ago mineral deposits in the Churnet valley became important, and gave rise to the copper industry which still exists at Froghall. In the 19th century many small coal mines existed round Kingsley, which expanded with short terraces of brick houses. Mining ceased years ago. Today many people live in Kingsley and commute into Stoke-on-Trent to work.
